00034 // This header file defines the Message class.
00035 //
00036 // IMPORTANT NOTE: Due to limitation of the C++ language, we have to
00037 // leave some internal implementation details in this header file.
00038 // They are clearly marked by comments like this:
00039 //
00040 //   // INTERNAL IMPLEMENTATION - DO NOT USE IN A USER PROGRAM.
00041 //
00042 // Such code is NOT meant to be used by a user directly, and is subject
00043 // to CHANGE WITHOUT NOTICE.  Therefore DO NOT DEPEND ON IT in a user
00044 // program!
00045 
00046 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_MESSAGE_H_
00047 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_MESSAGE_H_
00048 
00049 #include <gtest/internal/gtest-string.h>
00050 #include <gtest/internal/gtest-internal.h>
00051 
00052 namespace testing {
00053 
00054 // The Message class works like an ostream repeater.
00055 //
00056 // Typical usage:
00057 //
00058 //   1. You stream a bunch of values to a Message object.
00059 //      It will remember the text in a StrStream.
00060 //   2. Then you stream the Message object to an ostream.
00061 //      This causes the text in the Message to be streamed
00062 //      to the ostream.
00063 //
00064 // For example;
00065 //
00066 //   testing::Message foo;
00067 //   foo << 1 << " != " << 2;
00068 //   std::cout << foo;
00069 //
00070 // will print "1 != 2".
00071 //
00072 // Message is not intended to be inherited from.  In particular, its
00073 // destructor is not virtual.
00074 //
00075 // Note that StrStream behaves differently in gcc and in MSVC.  You
00076 // can stream a NULL char pointer to it in the former, but not in the
00077 // latter (it causes an access violation if you do).  The Message
00078 // class hides this difference by treating a NULL char pointer as
00079 // "(null)".
00080 class Message {
00081  private:
00082   // The type of basic IO manipulators (endl, ends, and flush) for
00083   // narrow streams.
00084   typedef std::ostream& (*BasicNarrowIoManip)(std::ostream&);
00085 
00086  public:
00087   // Constructs an empty Message.
00088   // We allocate the StrStream separately because it otherwise each use of
00089   // ASSERT/EXPECT in a procedure adds over 200 bytes to the procedure's
00090   // stack frame leading to huge stack frames in some cases; gcc does not reuse
00091   // the stack space.
00092   Message() : ss_(new internal::StrStream) {}
00093 
00094   // Copy constructor.
00095   Message(const Message& msg) : ss_(new internal::StrStream) {  // NOLINT
00096     *ss_ << msg.GetString();
00097   }
00098 
00099   // Constructs a Message from a C-string.
00100   explicit Message(const char* str) : ss_(new internal::StrStream) {
00101     *ss_ << str;
00102   }
00103 
00104   ~Message() { delete ss_; }
00105 #ifdef GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00106   // Streams a value (either a pointer or not) to this object.
00107   template <typename T>
00108   inline Message& operator <<(const T& value) {
00109     StreamHelper(typename internal::is_pointer<T>::type(), value);
00110     return *this;
00111   }
00112 #else
00113   // Streams a non-pointer value to this object.
00114   template <typename T>
00115   inline Message& operator <<(const T& val) {
00116     ::GTestStreamToHelper(ss_, val);
00117     return *this;
00118   }
00119 
00120   // Streams a pointer value to this object.
00121   //
00122   // This function is an overload of the previous one.  When you
00123   // stream a pointer to a Message, this definition will be used as it
00124   // is more specialized.  (The C++ Standard, section
00125   // [temp.func.order].)  If you stream a non-pointer, then the
00126   // previous definition will be used.
00127   //
00128   // The reason for this overload is that streaming a NULL pointer to
00129   // ostream is undefined behavior.  Depending on the compiler, you
00130   // may get "0", "(nil)", "(null)", or an access violation.  To
00131   // ensure consistent result across compilers, we always treat NULL
00132   // as "(null)".
00133   template <typename T>
00134   inline Message& operator <<(T* const& pointer) {  // NOLINT
00135     if (pointer == NULL) {
00136       *ss_ << "(null)";
00137     } else {
00138       ::GTestStreamToHelper(ss_, pointer);
00139     }
00140     return *this;
00141   }
00142 #endif  // GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00143 
00144   // Since the basic IO manipulators are overloaded for both narrow
00145   // and wide streams, we have to provide this specialized definition
00146   // of operator <<, even though its body is the same as the
00147   // templatized version above.  Without this definition, streaming
00148   // endl or other basic IO manipulators to Message will confuse the
00149   // compiler.
00150   Message& operator <<(BasicNarrowIoManip val) {
00151     *ss_ << val;
00152     return *this;
00153   }
00154 
00155   // Instead of 1/0, we want to see true/false for bool values.
00156   Message& operator <<(bool b) {
00157     return *this << (b ? "true" : "false");
00158   }
00159 
00160   // These two overloads allow streaming a wide C string to a Message
00161   // using the UTF-8 encoding.
00162   Message& operator <<(const wchar_t* wide_c_str) {
00163     return *this << internal::String::ShowWideCString(wide_c_str);
00164   }
00165   Message& operator <<(wchar_t* wide_c_str) {
00166     return *this << internal::String::ShowWideCString(wide_c_str);
00167   }
00168 
00169 #if GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00170   // Converts the given wide string to a narrow string using the UTF-8
00171   // encoding, and streams the result to this Message object.
00172   Message& operator <<(const ::std::wstring& wstr);
00173 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_STD_WSTRING
00174 
00175 #if GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00176   // Converts the given wide string to a narrow string using the UTF-8
00177   // encoding, and streams the result to this Message object.
00178   Message& operator <<(const ::wstring& wstr);
00179 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_GLOBAL_WSTRING
00180 
00181   // Gets the text streamed to this object so far as a String.
00182   // Each '\0' character in the buffer is replaced with "\\0".
00183   //
00184   // INTERNAL IMPLEMENTATION - DO NOT USE IN A USER PROGRAM.
00185   internal::String GetString() const {
00186     return internal::StrStreamToString(ss_);
00187   }
00188 
00189  private:
00190 #ifdef GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00191   // These are needed as the Nokia Symbian Compiler cannot decide between
00192   // const T& and const T* in a function template. The Nokia compiler _can_
00193   // decide between class template specializations for T and T*, so a
00194   // tr1::type_traits-like is_pointer works, and we can overload on that.
00195   template <typename T>
00196   inline void StreamHelper(internal::true_type dummy, T* pointer) {
00197     if (pointer == NULL) {
00198       *ss_ << "(null)";
00199     } else {
00200       ::GTestStreamToHelper(ss_, pointer);
00201     }
00202   }
00203   template <typename T>
00204   inline void StreamHelper(internal::false_type dummy, const T& value) {
00205     ::GTestStreamToHelper(ss_, value);
00206   }
00207 #endif  // GTEST_OS_SYMBIAN
00208 
00209   // We'll hold the text streamed to this object here.
00210   internal::StrStream* const ss_;
00211 
00212   // We declare (but don't implement) this to prevent the compiler
00213   // from implementing the assignment operator.
00214   void operator=(const Message&);
00215 };
00216 
00217 // Streams a Message to an ostream.
00218 inline std::ostream& operator <<(std::ostream& os, const Message& sb) {
00219   return os << sb.GetString();
00220 }
00221 
00222 }  // namespace testing
00223 
00224 #endif  // GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_MESSAGE_H_
